awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Multi-Mode Atomic Force Microscopy System for Research, Education and Outreach
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Major Research Instrumentation and Chemical Instrumentation programs. Professor Punit Kohli from Southern Illinois University Carbondale and colleagues Saikat Talapatra, Kyle Plunkett, Farhan Chowdhury and Senetta Bancroft are acquiring a multimode atomic force microscope (AFM). The microscope is a powerful tool for studying the surface of various materials.  It uses an atomic scale probe in which the pointed tip scans across a surface and measures the force between the probe and the surface.  This produces a high-resolution image of the surface with information on its structure and properties.  It leads to a basic understanding of complicated phenomenon that are in play at the atomic level.  Such knowledge is needed for understanding key physical properties of nanoscale materials and systems. An example of its use is in the synthesis of materials effective for treating contaminated water by photo catalytic methods to destroy organic contaminants such as dioxane or polyfluoroalkyl substances.  The instrument is employed by students in their research. It is used in classroom and laboratory instruction.  Therefore, the availability of this instrument significantly augments the learning experience of the students, faculty and staff not only at the SIUC campus but also beyond at other colleges and universities in the rural Southern Illinois region. 

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  The AFM is used to investigate the  mechanical properties at the nanoscale of organic, inorganic, and biological materials.  The fabrication and assembly of three dimensional (3D) architectural devices for electronics  and neuron circuits is being studied.  Strategic innovations in nanomaterials synthesis and design are under investigation for improving opto-electronics devices for energy storage and catalysis.  Materials for contaminant sequestration and bioremediation to improve water quality are also targeted. Another application addresses engineering a microenvironment for homogeneous epiblast stem cell renewal. The results have implications in multiple fields including cell mechanics, stem cell biology, and tissue engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award from National Science Foundation was a multi-disciplinary and multi-college effort.  The PIs on this award were from science, engineering and other education fields.  Because the award involved highly diverse fields and expertise, the award impacts multiple fields and disciplines.  In general, the transformative discoveries and inventions usually come from highly interdisciplinary and diverse experts with open minds.  Through this award, we are breaking the traditional boundaries separating science, engineering, and education fields.  We have accomplished this through collaborations among multi-departments across many colleges at SIUC along with other institutes.
About 15 undergraduates and ~20 graduate (~30% female) students extensively utilized the AFM instrument for their research (dissertation, thesis, posters, talks and manuscripts).  Multiple students who gained valuable experience on the AFM instrument joined high-tech industry (for example, Intel) and graduate and professional schools.
Six peer-reviewed manuscripts were published through this award.  A list of the peer-reviewed publications is provided in the final report of the award.  Further, five posters/presentations/talks also acknowledged financial support of NSF for the acquisition of the instrument.
The AFM was integrated into laboratory for the Instrumental Analysis course (CHEM 434, a chemistry senior course) at the Southern Illinois University Carbondale.  A total of sixteen students utilized AFM for performing AFM experiment in the Instrumental analysis course. Students mounted the tips on the sample holders.  They also mounted the sample holder on the scan head on the AFM instrument. They also aligned the laser on the tip and performed the photodetector alignment. They then acquired the data on samples for their reports using the Bruker Nanoscope Analysis software.  Based on this, a peer-reviewed manuscript was published in the Journal of Chemical Education.  For more information, please see:  "An Inquiry-Based Introduction to Atomic Force Microscopy Techniques through Optical Storage Disc Surface Imaging S. F. Bancroft, M. A. Ali and P. Kohli Journal of Chemical Education 2022 Vol. 99 Issue 8 Pages 3030-3038 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jchemed.2c00291."
We have also utilized the AFM for K-12 and community college education and outreach.  More than 126 middle- and high-school, undergraduate and graduate students toured and demonstrated the AFM.  About 30 John A. Logan Community College students and their instructor, Prof. Prachi Parashar were given demonstrations on the instrument (over about 3 years).  Five high school students were also provided this opportunity.
About 45 NSF-Research Experience in Undergraduate (NSF-REU) diverse students (> 40% minority and under representative) were given demonstration on the instrument.  Further, the students in the geology (GEOL 515), physics (PHYS 203), electrical engineering (ECE 560), and associate and undergraduate in the Saluki Summer Bridge program were also given demonstration.
Finally, the AFM instrument was also employed for solving a production problem for a local automotive part supplier (Nascote Industries).
